meaning_mnemonic: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <radical>barb</radical>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <radical>barb</radical>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <kanji>finish</kanji>ed.
reading_mnemonic: How does the fish lure maker test his newly <kanji>finish</kanji>ed lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>fins</radical> in <radical>private</radical>. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them <kanji>public</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You head out into the <kanji>public</kanji> where everyone can see your fins, but... things have changed. All people are the same. There are thousands of <reading>こう</reading>いちs walking around, and they all stare at you (though they pretend like they aren't).

meaning_mnemonic:
This kanji is the same as the radical — <kanji>straight</kanji> as straight can be.

It can also mean <kanji>direct</kanji>, because when you go straight to a place, you're going there directly. Depending on the context it can even mean <kanji>fix</kanji>, since fixing something means straightening out all the messed up crooked bits.
reading_mnemonic: Put food <kanji>straight</kanji> into your esophagus without chewing and you will <reading>choke</reading> (ちょく). You want to get straight to the most important part of eating — the digesting part — but if you don't follow all the intermediate steps, you'll end up choking.

meaning_mnemonic: If you give a <radical>woman</radical> a <radical>machine</radical> she'll <kanji>begin</kanji> learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to <kanji>start</kanji> before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
reading_mnemonic: Actually, before she can <kanji>begin</kanji>, she has to shear the <reading>shee</reading>p (し) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Run</radical> into <radical>oneself</radical> in a dream and you'll definitely <kanji>wake up</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: If one runs into oneself and you don't <kanji>wake up</kanji>, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an <reading>o</reading>bi (お) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from.

meaning_mnemonic: You jump on your <radical>scooter</radical> with a big <radical>bundle</radical> to go as <kanji>fast</kanji> as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there!
reading_mnemonic: You were going so <kanji>fast</kanji>, you only put on <reading>sock</reading>s (そく). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks.

meaning_mnemonic: You don't want to keep all the <radical>alcohol</radical> to yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), so you <kanji>distribute</kanji> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!
reading_mnemonic:
As you <kanji>distribute</kanji> the alcohol you say a <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい):

Here you go my friends
Alcohol for everyone
Never drink alone

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is an <radical>alcohol</radical>ic beverage containing a lot of <kanji>alcohol</kanji>. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it.
reading_mnemonic: As you lie on this beach, the <kanji>alcohol</kanji> keeps coming down a <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> has a <radical>roof</radical> and will teach you about the <radical>origin</radical> of many things. It's an <kanji>institution</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: What does <kanji>institution</kanji> start with? In (いん)!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and <radical>ice</radical> has brought this year to its <kanji>end</kanji>. Once you're in the long thread of winter and ice, you know the year will end soon.
reading_mnemonic: Whenever winter <kanji>end</kanji>s, you take the thread covered in ice, and lace it into your <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう).

meaning_mnemonic: You find some <radical>feathers</radical> that are so perfectly <radical>white</radical>, you want to <kanji>learn</kanji> more about where they came from and what they're made of.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>learn</kanji> that you should tie these white feathers to your <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building.

meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>car</radical> runs into a <radical>cloud</radical> you'll <kanji>revolve</kanji> around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway.
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>revolve</kanji> around the cloud <reading>ten</reading> (てん) times before it disappears and you're able to go through.

meaning_mnemonic: You give your <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>turkey</radical> so that it can <kanji>advance</kanji>. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance.
reading_mnemonic: You wave as the turkey <kanji>advance</kanji>s into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its <reading>shin</reading>s (しん) almost immediately. Ah!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> are knocked down by a violent <radical>tsunami</radical>, and swirl through the air to <radical>kiss</radical> your face gently as they <kanji>fall</kanji>. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew the flowers down. Amongst all the destruction, it's a pretty sight to watch them fall.
reading_mnemonic: You want to save these flowers that <kanji>fall</kanji> around you, so you take out a drying <reading>rack</reading> (らく) and place them carefully on it. Any flowers that fall will go on the rack like this, so can save them for later.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> bring beauty to the <radical>world</radical> of <radical>trees</radical>, but the <kanji>leaf</kanji> is what matters the most. <kanji>Leaves</kanji> are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!
reading_mnemonic: Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The <kanji>leaf</kanji> pops out and it shouts, "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!"

meaning_mnemonic: For a <radical>car</radical>, a <radical>tombstone</radical> is <kanji>lightweight</kanji>. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be <kanji>light</kanji> and easy to transport.
reading_mnemonic: What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right, a car. So you need some kind of <reading>car</reading> <reading>loo</reading>phole (かる). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but <kanji>lightweight</kanji> pebbles! But the rules say you can't use cars to carry tombstones, so you need to find a car loophole.

meaning_mnemonic: While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you bang your <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>car</radical> in front. Your scooter's wrecked, so you have to <kanji>carry</kanji> it home. You'll need a lot of <kanji>luck</kanji> to get that scooter home safely.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>carry</kanji> the scooter, your <kanji>luck</kanji> turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your <reading>um</reading>brella (うん). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>lantern</radical> is <kanji>open</kanji> for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>open</kanji> gate is in the water though, so you'll need a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case.

meaning_mnemonic: You chase a <radical>turkey</radical> up a <radical>tree</radical> to <kanji>collect</kanji> it. At least, you will once you've <kanji>gather</kanji>ed enough turkeys into this one tree.
reading_mnemonic: Once you've <kanji>collect</kanji>ed enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean <kanji>gather</kanji>ing even more turkeys!

meaning_mnemonic: You can <radical>eat</radical> all you want, but you'll still <radical>lack</radical> something to <kanji>drink</kanji>. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too!
reading_mnemonic: You get desperate for a <kanji>drink</kanji> and put some <reading>no</reading>ri (の) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>spikes</radical> growing out of a <radical>sheep</radical> with <radical>fins</radical>. Turn this thing into a <kanji>business</kanji>! You could totally charge people money to look at it. Sure, you could also donate it to science, but a business-minded person like you knows a business opportunity when you see one. Step right up! Just five dollars for a glance at the rare spiky mer-sheep!
reading_mnemonic: As you evolve your <kanji>business</kanji>, you let customers feed the sheep <reading>gyo</reading>za (ぎょう) dumplings, its favorite snack. For a nominal fee, of course. People love it when the mutant sheep eats gyoza out of their hands. Wouldn't you?

meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>tsunami</radical> hit ancient <radical>China</radical> and formed the <kanji>Chinese</kanji> country we know now as... <kanji>China</kanji>!

Sometimes this kanji also means <kanji>man</kanji>. In fact, it used to refer specifically to people of the Han dynasty, but over time evolved into a term for men in specific contexts.
reading_mnemonic: You peer closer at <kanji>China</kanji> and see one man, Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん), leading his troops into the vast country, ready to conquer all the Chinese people living in China!

meaning_mnemonic: If you've been walking all day, your <radical>foot</radical> is the last thing anyone would want to <radical>kiss</radical>, especially after wandering barefoot down a <kanji>road</kanji>. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet.
reading_mnemonic: What was this person walking down again? Oh, that's right – a <reading>ro</reading>ad (ろ). They were walking down a filthy road.

meaning_mnemonic: You blast your <radical>music</radical> loud so it causes a <radical>landslide</radical>, revealing the perfect soil for <kanji>farming</kanji>! Musically moved dirt is perfect for <kanji>agriculture</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The first person to come up with this <kanji>farming</kanji> method was <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth."

meaning_mnemonic: You look at some <radical>gold</radical> and notice a <radical>fault</radical> in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless <kanji>iron</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Do you know that movie, <reading>Tetsu</reading>o (てつ) the <kanji>Iron</kanji> Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>lip ring</radical> (or two in this case) is what you <radical>lack</radical>, it's going to be way easier for you to <kanji>sing</kanji> a <kanji>song</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Where are you always singing <kanji>song</kanji>s, by the way? In your <reading>ca</reading>r (か). It's not just you, either. Pretty much everyone likes to sing in their car.

meaning_mnemonic: If someone sticks <radical>bamboo</radical> in your <radical>eye</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> times, the first thing your brain does is <kanji>calculate</kanji> how painful it is. Your brain's pain <kanji>calculation</kanji> will determine how you calculate your next move.
reading_mnemonic: Next you want to <kanji>calculate</kanji> how much punishment your bamboo attacker deserves, so you call on <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん). Santa-san is always calculating how many pieces of coal the naughty children deserve, so he's perfect for this <kanji>calculation</kanji> job.

meaning_mnemonic: If you go up to a <radical>gate</radical> and press your <radical>ear</radical> to it, you'll <kanji>hear</kanji> what's going on on the other side. The people on the other side will have no idea you can hear their conversation.
reading_mnemonic: From the other side of the gate, you <kanji>hear</kanji> one of the people start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as "Hot Cross <reading>Bun</reading>s (ぶん)." You haven't heard this song since grade school. "Hot cross buns, hot cross buns~"

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> between <radical>five</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s is a <kanji>language</kanji>. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language.
reading_mnemonic: Another mouth joins in speaking the <kanji>language</kanji>, but it's green and scaled and... it's <reading>Go</reading>dzilla's (ご) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>say</radical> what you’re <radical>sell</radical>ing because people don’t like to <kanji>read</kanji>. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them.
reading_mnemonic: What are you forced to <kanji>read</kanji> aloud to sell? <reading>Yo-</reading>yo (よ) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>bird</radical> opens, you're most likely to hear a <kanji>chirp</kanji>. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp!
reading_mnemonic: The best way to experience the <kanji>chirp</kanji>-chirping of birds is to offer them <reading>na</reading>chos (な). Birds love nachos so much, it's a guaranteed way to make them chirp with delight.

meaning_mnemonic: You can use a long piece of <radical>thread</radical> during <radical>white</radical> <radical>water</radical> rafting as a safety <kanji>line</kanji>. Sure it's thin, but if someone goes overboard even a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard!
reading_mnemonic: The person who threw you that <kanji>line</kanji> of thread is actually a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> marked with a <radical>yellow</radical> X on the <kanji>side</kanji> of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm.
reading_mnemonic: Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is <reading>Yoko</reading> (よこ) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the <kanji>side</kanji> of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something about the <radical>circumference</radical> of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to <kanji>investigate</kanji> something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet <kanji>tone</kanji> of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them.
reading_mnemonic: "I came here to <kanji>investigate</kanji> this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう)!"

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <radical>stand</radical>ing under a <radical>tree</radical> and you <radical>see</radical> your <kanji>parent</kanji>, it's a good chance for a moment of <kanji>intimacy</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Standing under the tree, you go to give your <kanji>parent</kanji> a big hug, but you manage to bang your <reading>shin</reading> (しん)  on a huge tree root. Your parent pulls you in for a warm hug and rubs your shin. Despite the pain, it becomes an unforgettable "shin-timate" moment.

meaning_mnemonic: If you feed a lot of <radical>beans</radical> to a <radical>geoduck</radical>, its <kanji>head</kanji> will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, it can grow an incredibly large head. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads.
reading_mnemonic: As the geoduck eats more and more beans its <kanji>head</kanji> gets bigger and bigger, until finally the head explodes like an <reading>atomi</reading>c (あたま) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of its massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> on a <radical>cliff</radical>, a <radical>hair</radical>'s breadth away from the edge, when out of nowhere a <radical>geoduck</radical> slaps you in the <kanji>face</kanji>. The force makes you back away from the edge of the cliff, and your face is all slimy from the geoduck's residue.
reading_mnemonic: But where did that geoduck come from? As you turn from the cliff edge, you find yourself <kanji>face</kanji>-to-face with a <reading>cow</reading> (かお). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with a geoduck. You don't know why, but something about your face has upset the cow.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sick</radical> stick of <radical>dynamite</radical> is going to be <kanji>sick</kanji> forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good.
reading_mnemonic: Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? <reading>B.O.</reading> (びょう). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being <kanji>sick</kanji> is no excuse.

meaning_mnemonic: Let the <radical>sun</radical> shine into your <radical>ear</radical> while sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and make sure <kanji>most</kanji> of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone ever has.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Most</kanji> of this is for your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts.

meaning_mnemonic: Look at the <radical>ground</radical>! You spilled some <radical>water</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s, so I <kanji>request</kanji> that you wipe them up. I'd do it myself, but you're the one who spilled them, so I'm requesting that you do it. Pretty reasonable request, right?
reading_mnemonic: Oh, one more thing. I <kanji>request</kanji> that you wipe up the water with this <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう).

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Angle</radical> your <radical>sword</radical> correctly at this <radical>cow</radical> to <kanji>solve</kanji> its riddle. The key is to <kanji>untie</kanji> the cow with the sword without hurting it.
reading_mnemonic: Did I mention that you have to <kanji>solve</kanji> this whole riddle while on a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい)? No?! Whoops.

meaning_mnemonic: Did you know that those strange <radical>geoduck</radical> creatures were once used to make <kanji>page</kanji>s? Okay maybe not, but it makes for a memorable image!
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>page</kanji> is a <reading>page</reading> (ページ).
